>>especially if the code is at a reasonably well-factored state
> 
> Based on my previous expereince in general, I doubt it is.

If this is the case, there's no point in calculating a metric (973 
classes to JUnit-test) that you can't apply (because classes must be 
well-factored to be JUnit-tested (in general)).

Even if your manager gives you those 2,000 hours, chances are that you 
will explode the bugdet because you'll have to refactor along the way.

What I would do is start with integration tests and write unit tests as 
needed:

1) decompose your 973 classes into subsystems
2) write integration tests for each subsystems
3) when you isolate a bug in a subsystem, try to write a test for class 
containing the bug, refactor if necessary

Over time (not overnight...), you will improve the overall system but 
you will not have all your classes tested.  Depending on the type of 
project, the testing effort can also be made while maintaining the system.

-Vladimir
